awd_titl_txt: New Cosmological Constraints from the Lyman-alpha Forest
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigators will use intergalactic hydrogen maps to better understand how the Universe began. Hydrogen, the most common element in the Universe, is seen when backlit by bright objects.  The observed maps of hydrogen across the sky yields important insights about how and why the Universe looks the way it does.  This project will use new computer simulation techniques  to better explain the observed hydrogen maps. These simulations will be made available widely to scientists and the general public.  The simulations will also be shown in public talks and used to teach cosmology at UC Riverside.  Additionally, this program will develop a hands-on workshop for K-12 students, compatible with the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS), in both English and Spanish.

This program will produce new constraints on cosmological parameters from the distribution of neutral hydrogen in the Universe. A suite of cosmological simulations will be performed, and a public likelihood function made available to the community. The investigators will prepare for the first major data release in 2021 by the Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument (DESI). Improved models will be implemented for gas temperature and for elements other than hydrogen. The program will constrain neutrino mass and models of inflation. The results will enable a variety of other work on extensions to the standard cosmological model.  The astronomy workshops for K-12 students will include activities adopting a cognitive learning strategy, helping students to connect abstract concepts to concrete experiences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project has developed the field of cosmological simulations of the neutral gas in the Universe (the Lyman-alpha forest). Our cosmological simulations follow the evolution of a region of the Universe from the Big Bang until the time of observation of the neutral gas. Neutral gas is useful as it generally follows dark matter, but is directly detectable when a background light shines on it. An example from the simulations from this grant is shown as Figure 1: as a backlight shines through the gas it is dimmed, like a car headlight on a foggy day. The dimming of the light allows us to determine how much gas is present.

We have run several simulations (of a size not previously attempted) which include different properties for dark matter and for the state of the Universe just after the Big Bang. A variety of astrophysical processes describing how the gas is heated by galaxies and quasars were developed that were not previously included. This includes a new model for the way gas is heated by the very energetic light from quasars, active black holes, midway through the lift of the universe. Bubbles of ionized gas are created by the black holes, within which gas is heated, as shown in Figure 2.

We ran the largest single simulation of its type ever performed, something only made possible by the NSF's new supercomputer, Frontera. This simulation produced several PB of data and has made possible many analyses of black holes, of the state of the gas in the Universe and of galaxy formation. Figure 3 shows a rendering of the simulation, together with the largest galaxy it forms.

At the end of the simulations we compare the gas in the simulations to the real gas in the Universe and from the results of thic comparison we draw conclusions about the amount of matter present and its properties (including the mass of the neutrino, a light particle). We have pushed the boundaries of what is possible with these simulations in terms of size and accuracy, developing new models. We have also developed new machine learning techniques to allow us to accurately predict the results of simulations with cosmological conditions which differ from those actually run, and are now able to make predictions for a wide range of these parameters.

As part of the project, we have provided research opportunities for several undergraduates, mostly from under-represented groups. We have been active in community outreach, including to high school students, by performing workshops in schools around the Riverside area and to high school teachers in the Riverside Unified School District.
